displayed_text: Family Member: I’m like, wow. Patient: My, gosh. We was in Langa, and then Langa- Doctor: So did, was that part of the tour to see that or that was just you could not see that in just where you were going? Patient: Everything was part of the tour. Yeah. Family Member: Um hum. It’s all included. Patient: Everything is, and then you have some passages- Doctor: I mean, like the poor areas of the country, that was part of the tour, or you just look out the window and that’s what you see? Patient: When, when we went to Langa, that was, that was different than where they was going. So we, we, they had a package to go to Langa. We went to- Doctor: What’s Langa? Patient: Langa is a little town. Family Member: It’s a little town outside of Cape Town. Patient: Right.

Patient: Yes. Doctor: Okay. So along the way there with you say ‘well gosh what else do you need to take the samples for’ when you know us we do lots of research here. Patient: Sure. Doctor: So parts of that, I think we talked about this the last time, when I take extra samples I will then do actual research stuff on that… Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: …which includes you know growing it outside of you, putting it in mice, working with all – all sorts of other things. For me to do that I have to have a consent form that we’re gonna go over. Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: Um and uh this will allow me use with along with our other researchers for future use. Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: Um so you can see it was important for me to talk to the radiologist to make sure that we can do it safely and that we can get enough samples to make it worth everybody’s while. Okay. Questions. Patient: Um n- well observations. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: They – it it did say for example…

Patient: Or bend it backwards. The right side ain’t bothering me. It’s just that one that, well, the one that the screw came loose. Doctor: Okay. And, huh, any numbness or tingling? Patient: What? In my neck? Doctor: Your arms, your legs. Patient: No. And the only other thing that now and then is my shoulder blade from the day, from the first day that I was operated on. I was telling the nurse and everything while I was still in the hospital it felt like I had three shoulder blades at times. In fact, I told you that. Doctor: Is that getting worse? Or is it just present? Patient: No. It’s about the same. Doctor: Okay. How’s your heart been? Patient: All right. I woke up this morning. I’m not being smart, but (laughs) Doctor: Okay. But not- no chest pain? Patient: Oh, no, no chest pains. No. Doctor: Okay. How’s your hot flashes?

Patient: I don’t know. Doctor: Why do you make me work so hard? Patient: I don’t know. Doctor: My brain is on overdrive. Nice to see you both. I’m like racking my brain to see how to move forward and I’m just bummed out that you’re still in pain. Is this right? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Same place? Patient: Legs, mostly the legs, a little bit in the back, but I wanted to address the fatigue. That’s really… Doctor: Yeah, you just feel wiped out? Patient: Yeah. Family Member: Is that still a reaction from radiation six months ago? Doctor: No. Family Member: No, He shouldn’t have any effects from the radiation at this point? Doctor: No, I mean the only sort of culprit is untreated prostate cancer. You know if I had to sort of go back and we go a round of a bunch of pills

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.1 time: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::1 time

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.disagree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::disagree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.disagree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::disagree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.12 years or completed high school: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::12 years or completed high school

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Black or African American: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Black or African American

displayed_text: Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: anymore. Which… Patient: Just a second, even with the BET1? Doctor: No. For the BET1 that study will then kick in you’ll be registered to that study and they will give you from that study they will give you the Xtandi and the BET medication. Patient: Because ten thousand dollars a month is not something… Doctor: Well that’s okay. We can find ways around it and getting it covered if we need to. But chances are if you were to go on standard treatment, then yeah we’d have to wait and see what your insurance pays. Sorry about that. Family Member: That’s okay. Doctor: Okay. Patient: So um I think we should take it one step at a time and keep all our options open. So uh stay with the Xtandi and the Lupron and bring in the BET. And uh I I’m gonna be getting it from Midtown rather from here and they’ll know that? Doctor: Oh well once – what I was going to propose is that I give you the copy of the consent. If you want you can read it and uh if you’re ready to sign today you can, or we can schedule all the testing in anticipation of putting you on the study and all of that downtown and then that same day you can come in and sign the consent and do all the testing necessary. That gives you some time to think it over talk it over before signing. Patient: And you said it would just be a couple days I’d have to be there? Doctor: The two days are the long days. There are other days that you would be coming in and I just… Patient: For how long?

Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: you know and then that’s the information that says okay, what do we do next? Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: You know say I don’t like any of those trials that (names person) Family Member: Mm, hmm. Patient: Yeah, well I’m in favor of the trials. Family Member: There are a lot more side effects with the trials. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I’m not sure there’s more side effects; it’s just sort of we just have to put them out there, talk about them more. Patient: Yes. Doctor: You know chemotherapy has its own set of side effects Patient: Right. Doctor: But we have what the known benefits potentially are, whereas the clinical trials—we don’t know the benefits.

Patient: Right. Doctor: It’s sorta breaking through, right? You’re cancer’s already sort of figured out how it works. Patient: Right. Doctor: You’re options are A different standard of care pill, but we worry that if you go from that pill to the other pill, we don’t get a lot of mileage out of that because it’s too similar. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So then we could talk about chemo. (Pause) Patient: Okay. You heard about this cancer pen? Doctor: - no one’s gotten a rash and all that. Patient: - you heard about this cancer pen that they came up with? Doctor: You know how many cancer pills that are out? Patient: No, a pen! Pen! Doctor: Pen?

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: For this, I’ve got a, I think for this, the trial, they were able to use the experience with Germany to say you probably could start about here. You don’t have to start way down here. And I don’t think it’s the same exactly like a regular drug phase one. So I think they’re kind of already in a in a sort of Goldilocks spot. Patient: Okay. Okay. Doctor: So that’s the only difference between you know in Germany everybody gets, they individualize it based on what they looked at is how much of the scan is your cancer taking off. They try, they, they describe what they said that if you took up that much material, you need to get this much. Patient: Yes. Doctor: So they give, they dose it based on how much of an exposure. Patient: Um hum. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So I think, I think, again, what’s the best way to go? I mean the groups in Germany have way more experience doing this. Family Member: Um hum. Um hum. Doctor: Uh but you know it’s more complicated because you’ve got to go to Germany and all that, all those, there’s, there’s a layer to it. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Although you know saying that, you still would have to go away from home.

Patient: Right, okay. Doctor: So again, since you’re not eligible for that at this point in time - Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: A minimum PSA for that trial has to be above one. Patient: Okay. Doctor: One point zero. But just to prepare for the future – Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: I wanted to have that conversation with you. Patient: Uh hum. Sure. And this is the PSA level; you’re also saying we need to see something on the CT scan, right? Doctor: Correct. So for this particular trial, if the cancer is invisible, which will become non-metastatic. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: You would not be eligible. So it just has to do with; this trial is designed for a specific subset of patients so that cancer has to be both metastatic and hormone-resistant.

Family Member: Right. Doctor: So you’re not into it, but it, it just tastes really good. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: And then there’s the H___ C___, which is also pretty good. Family Member: I’ve heard of it. Okay. Doctor: Right across the street. Family Member: Oh. Patient: You know me better than that. Family Member: Seeing the head doctor. Patient: I’m kind of hanging outside of these. Doctor: Nice. It was good to see you. I’ve got to put up with this all by myself. Family Member: I know. I mean I got a little sick this year, too, so. Didn’t we tell you?

Patient: No. Doctor: That’s good. Um. Platelets are normal. (pause) Patient: Mmmm. I didn’t see that. (pause) Doctor: Six five oh, yeah, two months ago. So, you said you did read the scans or? Patient: Well, I saw them, you know, in the lab works screen. I didn’t, I didn’t look at the —- I mean, I couldn’t see the bone scans or anything like that. They don’t post those. Now, the PSA wasn’t posted when I looked at it, uh, this morning. Doctor: Umm, (pause) Patient: Okay. Doctor: Ummm, they compare it to the CAT scan. The CAT scan says there maybe new but more intense. Uh, but bone scans trump CAT scans. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Umm, so, we could technically say that that’s stable. Um. They comment more about your jaw this time. Patient: Okay. Doctor: They’re saying that it’s more intense. Uh, and they’re saying this could be more cancer then, you know, dental disease. Patient: Okay.

Family Member: Potassium. Doctor: Oh. Patient: Potassium and antibiotics. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Oh, your potassium is off. They came back two days later and said, oh, it was a little off. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Potassium was a little off. Doctor: Okay. We’ll, we’ll check you out for that. You know? You’re here because when Dr. S___, he did the lung biopsy or at least he told those guys to do a lung biopsy, it shows prostate cancer in your lungs. So not lung cancer. So in some sense a little bit of a relief but you still have your cancer of the – Patient: Of the prostate. Doctor: - prostate in your lungs. Now, you had that in twenty sixteen. It’s just that there’s more of it and slightly bigger. So that’s why I got you. When I went to, I sent you to Dr. S___, it was like well what are we going to do? Well, I need to take a sample. So he thought about going down this way. If you remember to try to get a sample from that, but he thought getting it through the outside would be just fine. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Patient: Which way did it get it? From the left side or right side?

Patient: That’s it. Doctor: No other medicines for pain, anything else for the allergies – Patient: No. Doctor: Or vitamins? Patient: No. Doctor: Okay. And when you were in the hospital, did they put any tubes or anything in, anything of that you still have. Patient: Yes, they put catheter in and uh they gave me I.V. at the beginning and made sure the catheter was out. Doctor: The catheter is out now? Patient: Now it’s not; See that is the problem. Uh catheter was not out when it was supposed to be scheduled; the catheter but two days before it was supposed to be taken out I Doctor: Even with the catheter in? Patient: Well, the catheter was blocked. Doctor: Okay. Patient: So I went again back to the emergency hospital and they made a mistake; they pulled it out. I still couldn’t pee. And I had peeing, but very little at the time. So they said it’s not doing it properly, so they put catheter back in. And they told me they shouldn’t have taken out. So the urologist told me; they should have flushed it and anyway, so.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Oxycodone immediate release five milligrams. Patient: No, that’s been set up for ten milligrams, and that’s as needed now after it’s been about two weeks since my radiation. Doctor: So it’s that ten milligram pill you take? Patient: No it’s two fives. Doctor: Oh, yeah. The OxyContin? And the OxyContin is thirty milligrams twice a day? Patient: Once a day; I’m taking it once a day now. Doctor: Once a day. Patient: Yeah, I’m taking it at night, so you know to get ahead of the pain. But it’s been pretty good. I haven’t been in much hip pain lately, hardly at all. Doctor: The Simvastatin twenty milligrams a day. That’s your Zocor. Patient: Yeah, right. Doctor: Your Flomax or Tamsulosin once a day? Patient: Yeah.

Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: That also tells you about chemo. Patient: Right. Doctor: The vitamin C part would only be done here. Patient: Right. Doctor: And, so, that would be, letting you go through that process to sort of say, “Okay. That’s the more traditional next step.” Um. The other one is a window phase one. Is that you have therapy, you’re not ready to go to chemotherapy, I’m willing to try something under our observations with blood tests and scans. That if the cancer would sort of wildly changing, we abort and do chemotherapy. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Umm. So, that would be sort of, in some ways, a gamble. But, some folks, everything we know about the drugs you’ve had so far, we’ve had people gamble at one point. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: And, then, the third one is we draw blood tests today, just to see the AR-V7 positive. That maybe that you say in what you’re doing now, and if you are AR-V7 positive, then we can sort of say, “Hey, yeah, let’s look at this other option,” if the immune therapy would be something that you would think about. Patient: Okay. What, what, what’s the, uh, uh, um likelihood of, of, if at that time the AR-V7, uh, testing comes back negative which means I can’t do that. Doctor: Right.
